title: Peter Tavy Walks

images.title: Tony Atkin / Peter Tavy
images.caption: Peter Tavy. The village gets its name from the church, dedicated to St Peter, and the River Tavy which runs close by.

images.title: Church of St Peter, Peter Tavy by Derek Harper, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Church of St Peter

images.title: Peter Tavy Inn, Peter Tavy by Chris Allen, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Peter Tavy Inn

images.title: Rob Purvis / River Tavy
images.caption: River Tavy. The river has given its name to the town of Tavistock and the villages of Mary Tavy and Peter Tavy. It is a tributary of the River Tamar and has as its own tributaries. It rises high on Dartmoor near Devil’s Tor and then winds its way down through Tavistock where it joins the River Tamar and forms the Bere peninsula. The Tavy also feeds Tavistock Canal, which was once an important trading route connecting Morwellham quay to Tavistock

images.title: Tony Atkin / Footbridge over the River Tavy
images.caption: Footbridge over the River Tavy

images.title: Mary Tavy war memorial by David Smith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Mary Tavy war memorial

description: This Dartmoor village is located just to the north of Tavistock on the River Tavy. The village is just off both the West Devon Way and the Dartmoor Way long distance footpaths. The pretty settlement includes a 14th century church and a noteworthy 15th century pub for refreshments after your walk. This circular walk from the village uses part of the West Devon Way and local country lanes to visit the neighbouring village of Mary Tavy. On the walk you can enjoy views of the River Tavy and the surrounding countryside. There's also a visit to the photogenic Harford Bridge at the southern end of the walk. To continue your walking in the area head north east to visit Tavey Cleave and Hare Tor . There's lovely riverside trails with waterfalls, interesting vegetation and several large granite tors. The wonderful Lydford Gorge is also near here and another major local walking highlight.
